content.raw: This makes a lot of sense to me. Using transport messages between the physics and sensor threads for high-bandwidth sensors seems like a recipe for delays. Can you create a separate issue for this? We should also write a design document
content.html: This makes a lot of sense to me. Using transport messages between the physics and sensor threads for high-bandwidth sensors seems like a recipe for delays. Can you create a separate issue for this? We should also write a design document

pullrequest.title: cache joint force torque for ode and dart

content.raw:
I tried to investigate the intermittent test failures on `REGRESSION_940__force_torque_sensor_frame`, 
and I verified that the correct force torque value is cached, but for some reason the FT returned by the sensor is wrong. 
I did not have time of investigate more, but my impression is that until a proper synchronization between the physics and the sensor thread is implemented,
a lot of confusing bugs like this will arise. 

A possible solution that came to my mind for not computationally intensive sensors with a high update rate (such as IMUs, FT, Magnetometer, Altimeter, etc)
 is to move them to a new `SensorCategory`, and simulate them directly in the physics loop, after the physics update. 
This would improve time determinism (for issues like #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1819/delay-on-imu-orientation-measurement and #!/osrf/gazebo_design/issues/1/model-time-synchronization-errors-in) that may be fundamental if someone is simulating the effect of noise on clock measurements (see #!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/19/improve-sensor-noise-models/diff). 
All other (computationally intensive) sensors that actually need to run on other threads will then instead need to implement proper synchronization, either by getting data from the transport or using classical synchronization mechanism if the call directly the physics API.
content.html:
I tried to investigate the intermittent test failures on REGRESSION_940__force_torque_sensor_frame, and I verified that the correct force torque value is cached, but for some reason the FT returned by the sensor is wrong. I did not have time of investigate more, but my impression is that until a proper synchronization between the physics and the sensor thread is implemented, a lot of confusing bugs like this will arise.

A possible solution that came to my mind for not computationally intensive sensors with a high update rate (such as IMUs, FT, Magnetometer, Altimeter, etc) is to move them to a new SensorCategory, and simulate them directly in the physics loop, after the physics update. This would improve time determinism (for issues like #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1819/delay-on-imu-orientation-measurement and #!/osrf/gazebo_design/issues/1/model-time-synchronization-errors-in) that may be fundamental if someone is simulating the effect of noise on clock measurements (see #!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/19/improve-sensor-noise-models/diff). All other (computationally intensive) sensors that actually need to run on other threads will then instead need to implement proper synchronization, either by getting data from the transport or using classical synchronization mechanism if the call directly the physics API.

content.raw:
Sorry, just saw the comment. 
The 940_force_torque_sensor_frame is just spawning a simple model with two boxes connected to the ground. In then does some steps of simulation (20) and checks the results readed by the the force torque sensors (with all possible combinations of SDF parameters) agains analytically compute one. 
The test failure is quite strange.. I will try to replicate it locally.
content.html: Sorry, just saw the comment. The 940_force_torque_sensor_frame is just spawning a simple model with two boxes connected to the ground. In then does some steps of simulation (20) and checks the results readed by the the force torque sensors (with all possible combinations of SDF parameters) agains analytically compute one. The test failure is quite strange.. I will try to replicate it locally.

content.raw:
I believe it was motivated by [this comment](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1603/fix-sporadic-failures-of/activity#comment-7255254).

Basically, if the `sensor` thread is calling [GetForceTorque](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1721/cache-joint-force-torque-for-ode-and-dart/diff#Lgazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.ccF644), it will get unexpected results depending on the state of the physics update cycle. By caching, we will always get a valid force and torque result, the down side is that it might come from a previous time step, but still better than zeros or uninitialized values.
content.html:
I believe it was motivated by this comment.

Basically, if the sensor thread is calling GetForceTorque, it will get unexpected results depending on the state of the physics update cycle. By caching, we will always get a valid force and torque result, the down side is that it might come from a previous time step, but still better than zeros or uninitialized values.

content.raw: I seem to remember somewhere we had issues where the call to GetForceTorque from the sensor update thread is not thread safe, given physics is on one thread, and sensor updates for ForceTorqueSensor is on a different thread, but I can't remember exactly which failure that was or where the issue was filed.
content.html: I seem to remember somewhere we had issues where the call to GetForceTorque from the sensor update thread is not thread safe, given physics is on one thread, and sensor updates for ForceTorqueSensor is on a different thread, but I can't remember exactly which failure that was or where the issue was filed.

content.raw:
The failure of `REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame` is fixed in commit [a03ef4d](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/commits/a03ef4defef2b2309d610749993a4e405bff0bd3?at=issue_1112_ode_dart_fix_ying).   
It has been tested with `300` continuous run of `REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame` with `0` failures, before it was around`10%`  

I didn't see the point of doing `CacheForceTorque` in the `UpdatePhysics` function, since the updated `wrench` is related  
to the `GetForceTorque` function only. Please let me know if I miss something.  

So based on this, I made another commit [8662646](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/commits/86626462fd5ae5431670abece90ff88b4178a68c?at=issue_1112_ode_dart_fix_yl)   

Feel free to merge the code if you agree @hsu
content.html:
The failure of REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame is fixed in commit a03ef4d.
It has been tested with 300 continuous run of REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame with 0 failures, before it was around10%

I didn't see the point of doing CacheForceTorque in the UpdatePhysics function, since the updated wrench is related
to the GetForceTorque function only. Please let me know if I miss something.

So based on this, I made another commit 8662646

Feel free to merge the code if you agree @hsu
